zone.line: from over him, shine forth brighter
and happier than before.
Woodville Herbert was the son of a poor
clergyman and had received a classi
cal education. He was one of those
few whom fortune favours from their
birth; on whom she bestows all gifts
of intellect and person wl with a
profusion that knew no bounds, and
whom under her peculiar attention
protection, no imperfection however
slight, or disappointment however
transitory has leave to touch. She
seemed to have formed his mind of
that excellence which no dross can
tarnish, and his understanding was
such that no error could pervert.
His genius was transcendant, and when
it rose as a bright star in the east
all eyes ^were turned towards it in admiration.
He was a Poet. That name has so often
been degraded than on the earth that it
will not convey the idea of all that
very
